sections.section: This tutorial shows how different parts of an application can be split between different processes using Callable Flow nodes.  The example uses an application which provides a raw HTTP/JSON service, and two separate applications which provide differently formatted timestamps for use in other flows.

This example uses a Callable Flow to provide that timestamp service, so it can be invoked from one or more message flows, but is not exposed outside the Integration Bus environment. A Mapping node is used to include the result of invoking the callable flow in the JSON response from the main flow.

A further extension to this scenario is that the calling flow can dynamically switch which flow it calls based on input data. You can also deploy updates to the Callable Flows without changing or redeploying the invoking flow.

sections.section: When you click Import, three applications will be created in your workspace: CallingParentApplication, CallableTimestamp and CallableTimestampAlternate.

CallableTimestamp and CallableTimestampAlternate each implement a single message flow with a CallableInput and CallableReply node. Both applications are configured with the same Endpoint Name. In this tutorial, these two applications will run in the same integration server as the other flows. With additional configuration they can run on different servers or even on different machines.

CallingParentApplication has a single flow called TimestampMyJSON. This exposes a raw HTTP service and uses a CallableFlowInvoke node to call one of the possible Timestamp flows. TimestampMyJSON also allows a value in the input JSON to be specified which allows you to dynamically invoke a callable flow from a different application, overriding the default value specified on the CallableFlowInvoke node.
These are explained in more detail when you move on to the Prepare tab, along with setup steps you need to complete before running the flows.

sections.section: Look inside application CallingParentApplication. There is a message flow TimestampMyJSON which has a CallableFlowInvoke node, with a label starting Call Timestamp Flow, updates body. This is configured with two names: the Target Application and the Target Endpoint Name. These are used to resolve which callable flow is used.

The mapping node Apply any LE overrides will set the value of LocalEnvironment/Destination/CallableFlow/Invoke/targetApplication if set in the input JSON message. This allows a differently named application to be called from the CallableFlowInvoke node, overriding the node option.

The two applications providing callable flows are built into a BAR file callable_flows.bar. Deploy this BAR file now. The rest of this tutorial's instructions will assume the use of the default integration server owned by TESTNODE. Move on to the Run tab to exercise the flows and see them working.

sections.section: Use the TimestampMyJSON.msgflow in application CallingParentApplication to run this tutorial. You should have already deployed the callable_flows.bar to the default integration server on your TESTNODE.

details.details: Open TimestampMyJSON.msgflow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy and start testing the flow. If you are prompted where to deploy, ensure you deploy to the same integration server as the CallableTimestamp applications.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the input message JSON message, no overrides, and click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node.
When the list of actions is shown, click on the Received HTTP reply message... item to show the output from the flow. Note that a timestamp has been added into the output message.
After you close the dialog, the path taken through the messageflow is highlighted. Click on the message icon on each connection to see how the tree is updated by each node.

Once you have tried the first message, click Send Message again and select the JSON message, override target application message. Note that it contains an additional tag overriddenApplicationName with value CallableTimestampAlternate.

Send that through the flow and note the output contains Alternate timestamp. If you look at the message tree before the CallableFlowInvoke node, note that a value is set in LocalEnvironment to override the targetApplication, which makes the flow under test invoke a different Callable Flow.

sections.section: You can further experiment with this scenario by changing the CallableTimestamp application and redeploying it, and then sending a message through the unchanged CallingParentApplication. Note that the behaviour changes immediately without needing to change or redeploy the invoking flow.

This tutorial shows the invoking and callable flow running in the same integration server, which requires no additional setup. You can also use these applications to experiment with running the invoking flow and the callable flow on different integration servers or different machines, but some additional configuration is required to enable cross-server communication. Look at the Knowledge Center links below for information on topologies in which these flows can run, and how to set them up.
